Title: Genius work... but a little bit to theatrical.
Review:
I find the original play text absolutely astonishing, but some of the gestures and poses of actors are more suitable for stage, rather than a movie set... But it's a small flaw for such an epic drama that will surely stay in the history of cinema forever as one of the best watching experiences ever.

The writing is snappy too. You can tell it was worked and worked and worried, going through several generations. It is easy to be mesmerized by this writing and acting, and miss the rare accomplishment of the camera-work. This camera is so fluid, you forget you are in one room. It moves from being a human observer, to being omniscient, to being a target. It is smart enough to seldom center on the element of most importance, so expands the field to all men.

This is very hard. Very hard, to make the camera human. So much easier to do what we see today -- acknowledge the machinery and jigger with it. Do we have a filmmaker today who could do this?

Title: s it fair and just to accept an innocent outcome.
Review:
The plot unfolds well, but the parts that Davis advocates are only ambiguous speculations. In fact, after verifying these things one by one, the child may or may not be the culprit. It's just that the initial work of the prosecution was not done well, and the cross examination of the defense was not done well. The case should be re investigated, rather than simply judged innocent. I am honored to see someone take a screenshot and quote this short review from eleven years ago as a vulgar representative of the masses. If I want to add now, I would say that the dereliction of duty by the power organs is one thing, and there is no fault with reasonable questioning, but there is a fault with the verdict of not guilty in the end. Because whether the masses blindly follow the speculation of institutions or male leaders, they are only being crushed. Literary and artistic youth criticize me for pursuing the truth and vulgarity, so as long as it contradicts the institutional perspective, is it fair and just to accept an innocent outcome.

Title: classic movie
Review:
Prepare to embark on an extraordinary journey through the realms of cinematic brilliance, as 12 Angry Men transcends the boundaries of greatness to become an unparalleled masterpiece. This timeless creation defies conventions and reshapes the very essence of film, leaving an indelible mark on your soul that will resonate long after the credits roll.

Within the simplicity of its plot and the confinement of a single room, 12 Angry Men weaves an intricately crafted tapestry of cinematic excellence. The limited space becomes a microcosm of the world, where the clash of profound human emotions and intellectual discourse ignites a symphony of riveting drama. Prepare to be spellbound as the power of the human mind unfolds, challenging our preconceived notions and leaving us breathless with anticipation.

Title: Any jury on this movie will reach the same verdict - A CLASSIC
Review:
12 Angry Men is a classic movie that shows how a jury of twelve men decides the verdict of a murder trial. The movie is set entirely in one room, where the jurors debate the evidence and the testimony of the witnesses. The movie is not only a thrilling and realistic portrayal of the judicial system, but also a powerful and insightful examination of the human psyche, the social issues, and the ethical dilemmas that arise in such a situation. The movie features an outstanding cast of actors, who bring to life the complex and diverse characters of the jurors, each with their own background, personality, and opinion. 12 Angry Men is a brilliant and timeless movie that will make you think, question, and empathize.

Title: An amazing experience
Review:
At first I questioned why a black and white film from 1957 has survived countless generations of technological iterations to take its place in the ever-innovating history of cinema. However, as I watched the film I realised that it should be in everyone's top ten films.

There are few films that are so brilliant and overwhelmingly uplifting. In the film 12 actors act as a jury to decide a murder case, and their decision will be about the life of a young boy. The 12 include people from all walks of life, all personalities and all ages. At first everyone thinks the verdict is a foregone conclusion given the overwhelming evidence...until one juror raises his doubts and the crowd begins to examine their evidence one by one. As the trial progresses, one piece of seemingly unassailable evidence is gradually overturned, and an unbelievable situation surfaced,the boy is acquitted.

Nowadays, when we watch a film, we care more about the beautiful images and the huge worldview. However, this film has no bright colours, no lengthy plot, just a vivid and simple story in a small room about human nature - something that has always been the same.

We often encounter similar situations in our lives. Do we try to find out the truth and avoid misattributions?

Title: Simple but powerful
Review:
Watching this movie I realised that a good movie and story doesn't come only from its size and complexity, but also from the impact and strength of the ideas that it shares and how much it is able to captivate you. Well this one really does captivate you, and it will surely make you think about it a long time after you are done watching it.

The entire action of this movie is happening inside only one room and within a few hours, the conflict is also not complicated but rather a small and intriguing one. The thing that makes it special as well is that within the length of the movie you and the characters are presented how important a wide range of opinions and visions is in taking a serious decision. And it also teaches the viewers the significance of communication between parties, having a good attention to detail and keeping an unbiased opinion as much as possible.

I consider the movie "12 Angry Men" to be a must see for any film enthusiast.

Title: best movie iN the World
Review:
12 Angry Men," directed by Sidney Lumet and released in 1957, stands as a timeless classic that delves into the intricate workings of human psychology, prejudice, and the pursuit of justice within the confines of a single jury room. The film's gripping narrative, stellar cast, and masterful direction have solidified its place as a cinematic gem that continues to resonate with audiences across generations.

Set almost entirely in a claustrophobic jury room, the film takes place after a murder trial has concluded, leaving the jury with the weighty responsibility of determining the fate of a young man accused of murder. The initial vote is overwhelmingly guilty, with only Juror #8 (Henry Fonda) standing firm in his belief that the accused deserves a fair and thorough deliberation.

The brilliance of "12 Angry Men" lies in its exploration of the complexities of human nature and the prejudices that often influence our decisions. As the deliberations unfold, we witness the jurors' gradual transformation from a unanimous guilty verdict to a more nuanced understanding of the case. Each juror's personality, background, and biases come to the forefront, creating a tension-filled atmosphere that reflects the broader societal issues of the time.

Henry Fonda's performance as Juror #8 is a standout, capturing the essence of rationality and empathy. His calm and composed demeanor contrasts sharply with the increasingly heated exchanges among the jurors. The supporting cast, comprising legendary actors like Lee J. Cobb, Jack Klugman, and Ed Begley, delivers exceptional portrayals of characters with distinct personalities and perspectives.

Sidney Lumet's direction is nothing short of brilliant. By utilizing the confined space of the jury room, Lumet skillfully ramps up the intensity, making the audience feel as though they too are participants in the deliberation process. The use of camera angles, lighting, and close-ups effectively accentuates the emotional turmoil within the room, adding depth to the characters' internal struggles.

The screenplay, penned by Reginald Rose, captures the essence of the original teleplay on which the film is based. The dialogue is sharp, incisive, and meticulously crafted to unravel the layers of the case and the jurors' biases. The pacing is deliberate, allowing each character's story to unfold organically, and building suspense as the group slowly inches toward a consensus.

Title: 12 angry men

But I was more likely with the written play, because it was fun that you could imagine what the story was acted, and it was better then the film, because you could use your brain to work on and to know what story was talking about and how they acted. Also, I like juror No.8 in the written play, because he was smart and brave. For example, juror No.8 was the only one to find out the problem of witness's testimony and acted hoe witness could did it. Another example, juror No.8 still insisted his vote, and he changed juror's vote and he saved the accuser's life at the end. I did not like the film because it's black and white, do not have good action, and have a lot of arguing. Also, sometimes the film is not connecting to the book and the film will add something that not belongs to the book. For example, the book did not talk about juror No.3 was crying and changing his vote at the end. And juror No.9 walked to juror No.8 and introduced him then the end. For other reason that I did not like the film because of juror No.3 because his act was so exaggerate and he cannot without his personal emotion. Such as: in Act 2, juror No.8 said that you want to see this boy die because you personally want it, then juror No.3 started to shouting and slapped on the desk said, " I'll kill you, I'll kill you."

Title: Prejudice explored
Review:
The film 12 Angry Men by Sidney Lumet gives us a picture of a very probably real life situation of negotiations taking place. It follows 12 white male jurors trying to reach a verdict in the murder trial of a Puerto Rican teenager who is accused of knifing his father. The task the jurors have is grave as their decision must be unanimous in whether this boy is to be given the death penalty. Despite the gravity of the situation, not everyone perceives it this way.

I enjoyed how the complexity of human prejudice is explored in the film. While its central story is based on the fact that 12 white jurors are reaching a verdict on a migrant Puerto Rican teenager's murder trial, the film also turns the prejudice on the viewer - in our assumption that all 12 men are the same.

It is highly enjoyable and spurs good thought.

Title: Excellent movie
Review:
The film is considered a classic because of the heroism and humanitarianism of Juror #8, because of the film's great direction of keeping such a small space visually fresh and because well it's a darn good story. I think a lot of people think the film is about an innocent man being freed by a jury that was initially hobbled by prejudice and vindictiveness. I.e. Juror #10 is a bigot, Juror #3 was trying to convict because of personal demons around his son. That is the first impression the film gives. But the film is a lot more nuanced than that. Instead, the film is about a man-who probably did commit the crime-being freed because the state failed to met its evidential burden. The first take on the film is a moral polemic, the second take is compelling legal drama.

Juror #4-the calm, always reasonable and engaged stockbroker brought to life by e.g. Marshall-is where the second take comes from in my mind. Had every single juror who was in the "guilty" camp to the bitter end been bigoted, unreasonable the film would be poorer for it. Instead Juror #4 *sincerely* believes in the defendants' guilt *until* the core of the case is dealt with. I.e. The eye witness. The character is the best arguer and while he is clearly engaged by the proceedings he is not emotional, personal. Juror #4 is the best juror qua juror because he demonstrates the virtue of reasonableness. This character is why the final film is so great and nuanced.

While Juror #8 is the hero of *this* story Juror #4 is the model we should strive to follow if called to serve.

Title: A screenplay masterpiece
Review:
Such a wonderful movie where the script brights the best. When a story has a limited location it is the script's job to hold the audience's attention through all the film. This movie does an excelent job at taking us in this trip of emotions, where we'll meet 12 men, all different but yet similar in many things: human morality. A simple task like getting an unanimous vote becomes a burdensome as we know more and more about the facts in the case.

In this story we get to empathize a lot with the characters, all 12 of them, the script does an exceptional job at creating individual arcs for each character, their personality and touch that they bring to the table.

It's an amazing film that puts into perspective what could happen when men have the power over other people, what could happen when men subliminally play the role of God.

Title: Perfection
Review:
Based on a play - this is a perfect courtroom (jury) vignette. I have watched it over 50 times overe the years, and always find somethig new - in the words, the camera, the characters, the mood... (I have read the one, two, and three star reviews - who complain it is in black & white, or set in just one room, or only had men!! They do not see the irony, that THEY are the jurors with irrational presuppositions that we are all wary of. THEY are the jurors in that room that decide the fate of a person. Read their reviews - and be very afraid. (Note: you can hate the film, but your reasons must be rational)). This is as perfect a movie, with deeper themes, as you can get. It is about democracy and prejudice and peer pressure and scepticism and free thinking and civic responsibility and privelege and hope. There are so many subtle cinematographic techniques that enhance the themes. This is a movie to be engaged with. Enjoy.

Title: Fantastic
Review:
This is a film with one hell of a slow burn. Small cast, small budget, only really taking place in two rooms. With a fantastic commentary on group think and conformity, this film is worth a watch for anyone interested in psychology and groupthink.

Title: So. Well. Done.
Review:
How one director can keep you at the edge of your seat for 1.5 hours with an entire movie set in one room is a true skill. A must see.
